title-group.article-title: A New Technique for Spleen Autotransplantation

author-notes.corresp: Isidoro Di Carlo, Department of Surgical Sciences, Organ Transplantation and Advanced Technologies, University of Catania, Cannizzaro Hospital, Via Messina 829, 95126 Catania, Italy Email: idicarlo@unict.it

abstract.p: Purpose. Although the efficacy of spleen autotransplantation is debated, this approach remains the only possibility for preserving splenic function after traumatic splenectomy. This report describes an alternative method for splenic autotransplantation in case of splenic trauma. Methods. After splenectomy, the organ was weighed and the undamaged part was cut transversely to prepare a segment of approximately 4 × 3 × 2 cm in size and of 35 g of weight to be transplanted. The greater omentum was pedunculated in its left lateral portion, and the previously prepared splenic tissue was implanted in a pouch created at the lower edge of the omentum. The omental peduncle containing the splenic tissue was fixed to the parietal peritoneum of posterior left upper quadrant of the abdomen where the native spleen was previously located. Results. This technique was performed in 4 patients after informed consent had been obtained. The functionality of the splenic implant was assessed after 3 months by abdominal computed tomography and scintigraphy. These exams showed the functioning of the trasplanted splenic tissue in all patients. Conclusion. This new technique needs further evaluation, but it appears to be an easy and safe alternative for spleen autotransplantation.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Although many methods for preserving the spleen parenchyma have been described during the past years,1 total splenectomy remains the most performed approach in case of splenic trauma.
Splenic autotransplantation is a possibility whose efficacy is debated, but it represents the only possibility of preserving splenic function in case of trauma.

Splenic tissue can regenerate in almost any part of the body, but intra-abdominal and subcutaneous locations are the most frequent. The peritoneal cavity is the favored site not only for convenience but also because this site provides the greatest chance for graft regeneration.2

The most frequent technique of spleen autotransplantation in humans consists in implanting sections of splenic parenchyma into pouches created in the greater omentum because of its favorable revascularization, portal drainage, and omental bacterial clearance.3
We describe here an alternative method for spleen autotransplantation to be adopted in cases of splenic trauma.

sec.title: Splenectomy
sec.p: Antibiotics were administered intravenously just before the incision and a nasogastric tube was positioned either preoperatively or after intubation, depending on the patient’s condition.

The patient lay on his back with a transversal sandbag under the thorax to facilitate spleen visibility. The abdomen was accessed by using a midline incision. After a rapid examination and removal of clotting, the mobilization of the spleen began as previously described.4

sec.title: Autotransplantation of Splenic Tissue
sec.p: After splenectomy, the organ was weighed and the undamaged part was cut transversely to prepare a segment of approximately 4 × 3 × 2 cm in size and of 35 g of weight to be transplanted.

The greater omentum was pedunculated in its left lateral portion (Figures 1A and 1B), and the previously prepared splenic tissue was implanted in a pouch created at the lower edge of the omentum (Figures 2A and 2B). The splenic tissue was fixed in the pouch through 2 stitches of Prolene 4-0 knotted without massive traction. By using the same material, 3 stitches of the same diameter were used to close completely the pouch and were knotted without massive traction (Figures 3A and 3B).

caption.p: (A) Greater omentum. The left lateral portion was prepared to allocate the splenic tissue. (B) A diagrammatic representation of (A)
(A) The prepared splenic tissue was positioned and fixed to the left lateral omentum. (B) A diagrammatic representation of (A)
(A) The free terminal portion of the left lateral omentum covering the splenic tissue. The omentum was fixed by using separate stitches to create a pouch. (B) A diagrammatic representation of (A)

sec.p: The omental peduncle containing the splenic tissue was anchored with 3 separate Prolene 4-0 stitches in the parietal peritoneum immediately below the left side of the diaphragm, where the spleen was previously located. This location was chosen to respect the physiological position of the spleen and to avoid torsion of the omentum (Figures 4A and 4B). A close suction drain was left in place.

caption.p: (A) The omental peduncle was fixed to the parietal peritoneum immediately below the left side of the diaphragm. This position was previously occupied by the entire native spleen. (B) A diagrammatic representation of (A)

sec.title: Results
sec.p: This technique was performed in 4 patients. The postoperative course was uneventful and the patients were discharged on the third, fifth, sixth, and seventh day, respectively.

The functionality of the splenic implant was assessed after 3 months by abdominal computed tomography (Figure 5), scintigraphy (Figure 6), and the absence of Howell–Jolly bodies. These exams showed the functioning of the trasplanted splenic tissue in all patients.

caption.p: Computed tomography scan of 1 of the 4 patients performed 3 months after the procedure. The image shows the omental pedicle with arterial supply and the enhanced image of the transplanted splenic tissue during the arterial phase
Scintigraphy (technetium 99m sulfur colloid by the autografts) of the same patient performed 3 months after the procedure, showing the splenic function

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Over the past few decades, the management of splenic injury secondary to trauma has evolved from splenectomy to splenorrhaphy to nonoperative management.5

The importance of splenic conservation following both blunt and penetrating injuries stems from its pivotal role in maintaining the body’s immunological function. Several techniques have been employed in splenic preservation and include splenorrhaphy, partial splenectomy, the use of topical haemostatic agents, conventional cautery, microwave coagulation, and mesh splenorrhaphy.5 These methods can be used in about 43% of patients operated with American Association for the Surgery of Trauma splenic injuries grade II or grade III lesions.6 But these techniques have a risk of rebleeding and are time-consuming procedures.6 When deep lacerations, particularly caused by penetrating injuries, do not permit control of bleeding, splenectomy remains the only possibility to safeguard the life of the patients.

Overwhelming postsplenectomy infection (OPSI) is reported to be the most important, and frequently fatal, complication of splenectomy. The overall incidence of septicemia remains low, but death rates for OPSI have been reported to be up to 600-fold greater than in the general population, with an estimated lifetime risk for OPSI of approximately 5%.7

Splenic autotransplantation is a method of preserving organ function and is performed mainly in trauma patients whose injured spleen must be resected.7 The results of this technique are controversial, but the beneficial effects seem to be evident in consideration of the low incidence of postsplenectomy sepsis in patients with spontaneous splenosis after splenectomy for trauma.8

Atherosclerosis observations after splenectomy for trauma also suggests a possible role for the spleen in lipid metabolism and splenic autotransplantation may be protective in conditions with increased lipid levels.9

The unresolved concerns related to this technique are represented by the choice of implant’s site and the amount of spleen to transplant. Comparative studies have demonstrated that autologus splenic grafting into the omentum results in better splenic regeneration and subsequent better immunological function compared with extraperitoneal graft placement.10 The vascularization of the greater omentum provides ideal conditions for the nutrition “per diffusion” during the stages of regeneration and neovascularization,11 but the precise reasons for superior graft regeneration and function in the omental position are not known.

Methods for splenic autotransplantation range from the use of homogenized spleen12 to the use of small cubes13 or thin and thick rectangular slices of different dimensions.13 Usually, these transplants are multiple, and up to 20 splenic slices implanted into the greater omentum have been reported.

Torsion of the implant, chronic anemia, postoperative intestinal obstruction, and subphrenic abscesses due to necrosis of the implanted tissue and due to the ischemic nature of the implants2 have been reported as complications of intra-omental splenic autotransplantation.14 The possibility that the suture thread used for the intra-omental implants contribute to the complications in this scenario cannot be formally excluded.15 Furthermore, torsion of the omentum at autotransplant’s site has been described as a cause of acute abdomen16 and aseptic necrosis of the graft.17

We developed this modification to avoid the consequences related to the standard technique, which consists of transplanting multiple splenic portions in the greater omentum. The standard approach lends itself to a greater risk for ischemia and abscess formation. To avoid the ischemic effect, we did not tighten excessively the stitches, and we used a monofilament suture to minimize the risk of infection.18

Moreover, multiple implants in the greater omentum that increase constantly in size could represent a risk factor for massive hemorrhage in case of abdominal trauma since the multiple splenic implants remain unprotected by the rib cage unlike the native spleen. For this last reason, the greater omentum containing a single piece of splenic tissue was secured in the position that was previously occupied by the native spleen. In this way, we avoided omental torsion and naturally protected the transplanted spleen also in prevision of its increase in dimension.

Another important aspect is the amount of tissue that should be implanted. Several investigators have demonstrated that 25% of normal orthotopic and vascularized spleen is sufficient for maintaining complete function,19 which is roughly 35 g in humans.20 Therefore, good splenic function cannot be achieved with less than 35 g of implanted splenic tissue; however, variable amounts, ranging from 24 to 100 g, have been transplanted with successful regeneration.7 In humans, there are reports on the use of various amounts of splenic tissue, from small fragments of 1.0 × 1.0 × 0.2 cm to large slices of 3 × 4 × 12 cm.21,22 In our cases, the transplanted tissue cannot be sliced thin because of lack of space in the new pouch of greater omentum.

It is known that Howell–Jolly bodies are normally removed by the spleen and that they are evident after splenectomy and disappear in some patients with splenosis. All our patients showed the absence of Howell–Jolly bodies. Some authors consider their presence a morphologic finding, but they state that quantitative assessment of splenic activity cannot be made on the basis of their absence. Splenic scintigraphy is considered a more sensitive indicator of splenic tissue activity than blood studies9 since it demonstrates the phagocytic function of the splenic autografts. The uptake of technetium 99m sulfur colloid by the autografts demonstrated that phagocytic function was preserved even in the absence of the main vascular pedicle.20 In the present case, scintigraphy was performed 3 months after the autotrasplantation, allowing the spleen time to regenerate.20
This new technique requires further evaluation, but it appears to be an easy, safe, and useful alternative to conventional splenic autotransplantation.
